revisions.rev:
{{Infobox artist discography |Artist = [[Jamelia]] |Image = Jammelia.jpg |Image size = 200px |Caption = [[Jamelia]] performing live on stage. |Studio = 3 |Studio link = Studio albums |Compilation = 2 |Comp link = Compilation album |Singles = 14 |Option = 5 |Option name = Other appearances |Option link = Other appearances |Option color = lightsalmon |1Option = 4 |1Option name = DVDs |1Option link = DVDs |1Option color = beige |Music videos = 15 |References = Yes |Ref link = References }} The [[discography]] of [[Jamelia]], a Jamaican-British [[R&B]] singer, consists of three [[studio album]]s, one [[greatest hits]] album, and fourteen [[single (music)|single]]s, fifteen [[music video]]s, and one live DVD of a concert performance. She has contributed to the albums of two other artists, and appeared on two [[soundtrack album]]s. Jamelia signed with [[Capitol Records]] in 1996, and her debut single, "[[So High]]", was released on 3 May 1999. It failed to chart and she left the record company before an album was released. Later that year, Jamelia released "[[I Do (Jamelia song)|I Do]]" with [[Parlophone]], which was followed up in 2000 with her first top five single, titled "[[Money (Jamelia song)|Money]]", and her debut album ''[[Drama (Jamelia album)|Drama]]''. Jamelia's second album, ''[[Thank You (Jamelia album)|Thank You]]'', released in 2003, is her most successful to date, peaking at number 4 on the [[UK Albums Chart|United Kingdom Albums Chart]], at number 16 in New Zealand, and at number 21 in Ireland. It also charted in Australia and mainland Europe, but in much lower positions. The album's [[lead single]]s were "[[Bout (song)|Bout]]", a reggae-style song that features a rap from [[Rah Digga]], and pop/dance song "[[Superstar (Jamelia song)|Superstar]]". "Bout" charted at 37 on the [[UK Singles Chart]], but "Superstar" fared much better, entering the singles chart at number 8 and climbing to number 3, its peak position, after four weeks.{{cite episode |title=Top 40 |series=The Radio 1 Chart Show |credits=[[Wes Butters]] (presenter) |network=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]] |station=[[BBC Radio 1]] |airdate=21 September 2003 }}{{cite episode |title=Top 40 |series=The Radio 1 Chart Show |credits=[[Wes Butters]] (presenter) |network=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]] |station=[[BBC Radio 1]] |airdate=12 October 2003 }} It was also the 26th [[2003 in British music charts|best selling single of 2003]].{{cite episode |title=Top 40 of 2003 |series=The Radio 1 Chart Show |credits=[[Wes Butters]] (presenter) |network=[[British Broadcasting Corporation]] |station=[[BBC Radio 1]] |airdate=1 January 2004 }} The next single taken from ''Thank You'' was [[Thank You (Jamelia song)|the title track]], which peaked at number 2 in the UK. Both "Superstar" and "Thank You" are Jamelia's most successful single releases to date, appearing in many singles charts worldwide. ''Thank You'' was subsequently re-released with two new songs: "[[See It in a Boy's Eyes]]" and "[[DJ (Jamelia song)|DJ]]". In 2004, Jamelia performed "[[Universal Prayer (song)|Universal Prayer]]" with [[Tiziano Ferro]] for release on his album ''[[111 Centoundici]]''. The song also appears on ''Unity'', the soundtrack for the [[2004 Summer Olympics]]. The song was released as a single in mainland Europe, and reached number 1 in Italy. Later that year, she recorded "[[Stop! (Sam Brown song)#Jamelia version|Stop]]", a [[cover version|cover]] of the 1988 song recorded by [[Sam Brown (singer)|Sam Brown]]. It is included on the [[Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (film)#Soundtrack|soundtrack album]] to the feature film ''[[Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (film)|The Edge of Reason]]'', and was released as a [[A-side and B-side#Double A-side|double A-side]] with "DJ". At the end of 2004, Jamelia recorded an updated version of the [[charity record]] "[[Do They Know It's Christmas?]]" as a part of [[Band Aid (band)#Band Aid 20|Band Aid 20]];{{Cite news|title=Stars gather for Band Aid, 20 years on |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-326065/Stars-gather-Band-Aid-20-years-on.html |work=[[Daily Mail]] |publisher=[[Associated Newspapers]] |date=14 November 2004 |accessdate=6 April 2009 }} it became the [[Christmas Number One]].{{Cite news|first=Daniel |last=Saney |title=Band Aid 20 clinches Christmas number one |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/showbiz/a17775/band-aid-20-clinches-christmas-number-one.html |publisher=[[Digital Spy]] |date=20 December 2004 |accessdate=6 April 2009 }} Jamelia's third and most recent album, ''[[Walk with Me (album)|Walk with Me]]'', was released in 2006. It was not as commercially popular as ''Thank You'', reaching number 20 on the albums chart in the UK; the three singles that were released from the album also fared worse than the singles from ''Thank You''. "[[Something About You (Jamelia song)|Something About You]]" and "[[Beware of the Dog]]" peaked just inside the top 10; "[[No More (Jamelia song)|No More]]" fell short of the top 40. Despite being labelled a "[[one-hit wonder]]" by members of the UK music industry,{{Cite news|title=X Factor judges round on 'one-hit wonder' Jamelia |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-422150/X-Factor-judges-round-hit-wonder-Jamelia.html |work=[[Daily Mail]] |publisher=[[Associated Newspapers]] |date=12 December 2006 |accessdate=6 April 2009 }} Jamelia has had seven singles chart inside the UK Top 10, and only three chart outside the UK Top 40.{{Cite book|editor1-first=David |editor1-last=Roberts |others=[[Dave McAleer|McAleer, Dave]] |title=[[Guinness Book of British Hit Singles & Albums]] |edition=19 |year=2007 |month=June |publisher=[[HiT Entertainment]] |isbn=1-904-99410-5 }}{{Cite book|title=[[The Virgin Book of British Hit Singles]] |date=6 November 2008 |publisher=[[Virgin Books]] |isbn=0-753-51537-7 }} Jamelia has announced that she plans to release her fourth album in 2012.{{Cite news|first=Daniel |last=Kilkelly |title=Jamelia reveals chart comeback plans |url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/a145976/jamelia-reveals-chart-comeback-plans.html |publisher=[[Digital Spy]] |date=7 February 2009 |accessdate=6 April 2009 }} ==Albums== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:left;" ! width="30" rowspan="2"| Year ! width="230" rowspan="2"| Album details ! colspan="10"| Peak chart positions ! rowspan="2"| Certifications |- !style="width:3em; font-size:75%;"| [[UK Albums Chart|UK]]
